nodes.bodyText: Nuance thing: PersistenceNotifier has many javadoc comments. Just for having the same style I would add them also here.
It is just my personal taste that I dislike static methods: they are harder to mock. Were these non-static methods, one could mock them the usual way.

I am not convinced this is a good name for this class. I would rename it to AzureImageService or something similar.
Reason: there is a class AzureClient, containing a large amount of methods, almost all pure azure calls. The AzureImageClient class here, however, contains only one such method.
do we expect to have multiple resources with the same resource reference?
Yes, because every stack creates a new managed image record into the resource table. But, I think it's enough to know that is there any image in REQUESTED status.
We should use getByResourceGroup() here, as we have the name and RG, too
pls log RG creation
this should be in the same line as previous line
shouldn't we throw this, too instead of just logging it?
should be "SyncPollingScheduler <Boolean>"
could you pls extract this logic to a createCustomImage() method? I know it is mainly not your code, but anyways :D
pls check now
Could you pls write a unit test for this?
pls log the result
this is a HUGE table, could we speed up the full table scan with including resourceType in the query, with probably an index on it?
maybe not a List?
Why not throw new CloudConnectorException instead?
I would rename it to PersistenceRetriever. The name notifier is misleading as it is not notifying, but it is used to manipulate persisted resources
The spring data jpa and the stream convention for naming methods returning optionals is to name them findSomething. We do not need to follow that convention but could actually come handy.
It would make sense to name it findVirtual ...
I would name it as findVirtual... as it resembles more the jpa and stream method naming convention.
I would name it as ...Task

I would extract this method to AzureClient. Currently almost all of the calls made to azure are located in that class.
A subsequent refactoring (another ticket) could be to extract thematic clients from that class.
I will create a ticket to refactor the AzureClient.
The code here in the catch clause is already extracted to AzureUtils.convertToCloudConnectorException method. You could reuse that.
I would name this interface as ResourceRetriever, similar to ResourcePersister
In the persister class there is a persist() method. It always returns null. By introducing a retrieving mechanism it might make sense to eliminate that method.

Also, there are 3 interfaces for some kind of manipulation. It might make sense to apply a naming structure, like ResourcePersister - ResourceNamer - ResourceRetriever. Or, add a new package named as resource and move the classes there as Persister - Namer - Retriever. This could go as a followup refactoring jira.
The test name is strange, I guess you wanted testGetByResourceReferenceShouldReturnEmptyList
I would call it AzureImageIdProviderService - and rename it later to ImageIdService once there are also other methods
I would move this class to package image -- sorry I did not write this in my first review.

I would move code calling azure directly into AzureClient itself. It is very useful to keep all that code in one file (maybe later on in one package), in that way we know what operations we have defined on azure.
I would move this code into AzureClient, to have all operations on azure in one place.
